title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe a solution for reversing the pattern of economic damage seen for SO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabofacaqGpbWaaSbaaSqaaiaabkdaaeqaaaaa@3A82@ in the eastern United States, such as any of the following:

· Use scrubbers to remove SO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabofacaqGpbWaaSbaaSqaaiaabkdaaeqaaaaa@3A82@

· Use fluidized bed combustion in coal-burning power plants

· Use of flue gas desulfurization in coal-burning power plants

· Coal washing/beneficiation/cleaning to remove SO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabofacaqGpbWaaSbaaSqaaiaabkdaaeqaaaaa@3A82@

· Burn higher grade coals in power plants

· Reduce coal or oil burning by producing more electricity by a renewable energy or low- or no SO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabofacaqGpbWaaSbaaSqaaiaabkdaaeqaaaaa@3A82@ emitting energy source (e.g., solar, wind, hydropower, nuclear, natural gas)

· Enact a more stringent SO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabofacaqGpbWaaSbaaSqaaiaabkdaaeqaaaaa@3A82@ trading program to further decrease SO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabofacaqGpbWaaSbaaSqaaiaabkdaaeqaaaaa@3A82@ emitted from coal-fired power plants

The response describes a solution for reversing the pattern of economic damage seen for SO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabofacaqGpbWaaSbaaSqaaiaabkdaaeqaaaaa@3A82@ in the eastern United States, such as one of the following:

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe an area in the United States that would likely experience very low levels of photochemical smog such as the following:

· A rural area in the upper western areas (e.g., Northwest, Montana, the Dakotas) where both nitrogen oxides and VOCs MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabAfacaqGpbGaae4qaiaabohaaaa@3B60@ are low would have low levels of smog. Since photochemical smog forms when NO X MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aab6eacaqGpbWaaSbaaSqaaiaabIfaaeqaaaaa@3AA3@ and VOCs MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabAfacaqGpbGaae4qaiaabohaaaa@3B60@ react in sunlight, these areas are the least likely to experience photochemical smog.

The response describes an area in the United States that would likely experience very low levels of photochemical smog such as the following:

· A rural area in the upper western areas (e.g., Northwest, Montana, the Dakotas) where both nitrogen oxides and VOCs MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabAfacaqGpbGaae4qaiaabohaaaa@3B60@ are low would have low levels of smog. Since photochemical smog forms when NO X MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aab6eacaqGpbWaaSbaaSqaaiaabIfaaeqaaaaa@3AA3@ and VOCs MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabAfacaqGpbGaae4qaiaabohaaaa@3B60@ react in sunlight, these areas are the least likely to experience photochemical smog.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify one of the mapped pollutants and does not explain how the average annual amount of precipitation and the location of the sources of the pollutant lead to its pattern of economic damage such as the following:

· Sulfur dioxide and/or nitrous oxides from coal-fired power plants and/or other industries that combust coal or oil in the Midwest/eastern United States can form large volumes of acid rain in regions of high precipitation.

The response identifies one of the mapped pollutants and explains how the average annual amount of precipitation and the location of the sources of the pollutant lead to its pattern of economic damage such as the following:

· Sulfur dioxide and/or nitrous oxides from coal-fired power plants and/or other industries that combust coal or oil in the Midwest/eastern United States can form large volumes of acid rain in regions of high precipitation.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify one of the mapped air pollutants and does not make a claim using evidence that supports the assertion that incorporating crop rotation will reduce emissions of one of the mapped air pollutants, such as any of the following:

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify and does not describe one method that emerged during the Green Revolution that would not contribute to air pollution but has negatively impacted soil erosion, such as any of the following:

· Increase in irrigation techniques (increased use of flood or furrow irrigation) can increase the amount of runoff, increasing soil erosion.

· Use of tillers or increased tilling increases soil erosion as soil is disturbed before planting.

· Monoculture farming is the practice of planting the same crop on the same area of land year after year. This practice depletes soil of nutrients (chemical soil erosion) and reduces organic matter in soil, altering soil structure and composition, making it more prone to erosion.

· Multi-cropping or double-cropping involves growing two or more crops in succession, one after the other, which typically depletes soil of nutrients (chemical erosion) and may weaken soil structure, making it more prone to erosion.

· GMOs MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabEeacaqGnbGaae4taiaabohaaaa@3B5B@ /High-yield varieties typically draw nutrients from the same soil layer (strata), causing nutrient depletion (chemical soil erosion).

The response identifies and describes one method that emerged during the Green Revolution that would not contribute to air pollution but has negatively impacted soil erosion, such as one of the following:

· Increase in irrigation techniques (increased use of flood or furrow irrigation) can increase the amount of runoff, increasing soil erosion.

· Use of tillers or increased tilling increases soil erosion as soil is disturbed before planting.

· Monoculture farming is the practice of planting the same crop on the same area of land year after year. This practice depletes soil of nutrients (chemical soil erosion) and reduces organic matter in soil, altering soil structure and composition, making it more prone to erosion.

· Multi-cropping or double-cropping involves growing two or more crops in succession, one after the other, which typically depletes soil of nutrients (chemical erosion) and may weaken soil structure, making it more prone to erosion.

· GMOs MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaai aabEeacaqGnbGaae4taiaabohaaaa@3B5B@ /High-yield varieties typically draw nutrients from the same soil layer (strata), causing nutrient depletion (chemical soil erosion).

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim that proposes a solution to the problem identified in part (f), such as any of the following:

Irrigation (problem in part (f)).

· Use drip irrigation/spray irrigation

· Use timers for watering

· Water plants in the early morning/late evening to reduce evaporation

Increased Tillage/advanced tilling techniques (problem in part (f)).

· Use conservation tillage (e.g., no-till) to reduce soil erosion

· Use organic material/green manure to reduce or prevent soil erosion

· Use crop rotation to improve soil structure and reduce erosion

· Use terracing

Monoculture farming or Multi-cropping (problem in part (f)).

· Use intercropping/polyvarietal cultivation/crop rotation

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one disadvantage or unintended consequence that could result from the solution proposed in part (g), such as any of the following:

Use drip irrigation/spray irrigation, use timers for watering, water plants in the early morning/late evening to reduce evaporation, or use of soil moisture sensors to efficiently gauge water needed for optimal crop growth (solution in part (g)).

· Drip irrigation tubes can get clogged or the plastic degrades so that it doesn’t deliver any water

· Spraying water can be blown away when windy

· Pipes and hoses needed for drip irrigation are expensive.

· Soil moisture sensors would be an added expense

Use conservation tillage (e.g., no-till) to reduce soil erosion or use organic material/green manure to reduce or prevent soil erosion (solution in part (g)).

· Conservation tillage practices can require more herbicides

· Conservation tillage (e.g., no-till) practices can require purchasing new equipment

· Use of organic material/green manure can require increased labor/add expense

Use crop rotation (solution in part (g)).

· Crop rotation may decrease yields

· Crop rotation requires purchase of new seed varieties and decrease profit

Use terracing (solution in part (g)).

· Terracing often requires intense labor and could be expensive
